author: sky.cactus
content: One should be careful to differentiate users from holders.  An actor can be both a user and a holder at the same time, but need not be.  Price decreases relative to <unit of account> negatively affect holders, not users.  Arguably, it positively affects users due to reduction in usage costs, though this is marginal compared to gas price fluctuations.

author: potuz
content: On the issue of price I have never seen a counter argument to the most naive one. I often hear that the network is unusable because of high fees.  But one can argue that it's not fees that are high but that the fiat price of eth is high. The only relevant measure is the percentage of the fee with respect to the typical transaction one makes. If you needed to spend thousands of ETH to buy bread, you wouldn't mind a few Gwei spent in tx fees. Sure, we can scale, several orders of magnitude and use L2s or whatnot to lower fees, but if markets price this in and the price of eth continues to increase, then fees will again be "high" pricing out the poor.

author: sky.cactus
content: If a > 33% of validators suddenly go offline the chain will stop finalizing, but it will self heal eventually.  While undesirable, it is working as intended and there is nothing additional we need to do from a technical standpoint to address it.  The problem is already accounted for and coded against.

author: sky.cactus
content: Validating is intentionally made to be relatively easy, so a person can simply start validating from another location if their location goes offline (though, take care to protect against double-signing if you are moving to a new machine without cleanly shutting down the first!)

author: peter.davies
content: This should provide an incentive to run your validator from somewhere that isn't AWS East. More generally stakers should aim to run their validators in a way that avoids correlated failures with other validators. The penalties for uncorrelated failures are much more minor than correlated ones.
